chapter: Genital System-Pathology Of Male Genital Tract

questions.question: A 42-year-old male presents with testicular pain and swelling. Physical examination reveals a palpable mass. Subsequent biopsy of the mass provides important diagnostic insights. Which of the following statements regarding sex cord-stromal tumours in males are true? A) They are classified into three main subtypes: Leydig cell and Sertoli cell tumours and yolk sac tumours. B) Sertoli cell tumours are commonly associated with hormonal abnormalities. C) Histologically, Leydig cell tumors demonstrate golden pigment with reinke crystals with eosinophilic cytoplasmic inclusions. D) Sertoli cell tumours are often associated with Carney’s complex and are typically malignant.
questions.explanation: Correct answer: C) C Explanation: Sex cord-stromal tumours have two major subtypes: Leydig cell and Sertoli cell tumour. Pathological features correlating with malignancy include large size, necrosis, infiltrative borders, anaplasia, mitotic activity, vascular-lymphatic invasion, and extratesticular extension. Leydig cell tumour Sertoli cell tumour Hormonal involvement It often involves androgens, oestrogens, and corticosteroids. Hormonally silent. Conditions associated with Klinefelter syndrome. Cryptorchidism. Renal cell carcinoma. Carney complex. Peutz-Jeghers syndrome. Familial adenomatous polyposis. Malignancy 10% (in adults) 10% Gross Circumscribed nodules, usually < 5 cm in diameter. They have a distinctive golden brown, homogeneous appearance on cut surfaces. Firm, small nodules with a homogeneous grey-white to yellow cut surface. Histology The tumour cells resemble their normal counterparts. They are large in size and have round or polygonal cell outlines , abundant granular eosinophilic cytoplasm , and a round central nucleus. The cytoplasm frequently contains lipid droplets , vacuoles , or lipofuscin pigment and, most characteristically, rod-shaped Reinke crystalloids (25% of the tumours). The tumour cells are arranged in distinctive trabeculae that tend to form cord-like structures and tubules. Image
questions.chapter_heading: Genital System-Pathology Of Male Genital Tract

questions.question: A 32-year-old male presents with multiple, small, flesh-coloured growths on the shaft of his penis. A biopsy is performed, and histopathology reveals hyperkeratosis, acanthosis, and koilocytosis. Which of the following is the most likely causative agent of his condition?
questions.explanation: Correct answer: A) HPV 6 and 11 Explanation: Condyloma acuminatum: It is a benign sexually transmitted wart caused by human papillomavirus (HPV). Low risk HPV serotypes (HPV 6 and, less frequently, HPV 11) are the most frequent cause. Morphology: Gross Condylomata acuminata may arise in the external genitalia or perineal areas. Histology The lining cells frequently display perinuclear cytoplasmic vacuolisation ( koilocytosis ), which is a characteristic of HPV infection. Treponema pallidum (Option B) causes syphilis, which can present with a painless ulcer (chancre) in its primary stage. It can cause condyloma lata in the secondary stage. HSV type 2 (Option C) typically causes genital herpes, characterized by painful vesicles and ulcers on the genitalia. Chlamydia trachomatis (Option D) causes chlamydial infections, which can lead to urethritis, cervicitis, and pelvic inflammatory disease.
questions.chapter_heading: Genital System-Pathology Of Male Genital Tract

questions.question: A 65-year-old male presents with difficulty in urination and frequent nocturia. Digital rectal examination reveals a firm, irregular prostate. A subsequent prostate-specific antigen (PSA) test shows elevated levels. A transrectal ultrasound-guided prostate biopsy is performed, and the pathology report provides a Gleason score. Which of the following statements regarding the Gleason score in prostate cancer diagnosis is correct for this patient? tumor.

options.A: The Gleason score indicates the stage of prostate cancer.
options.B: A Gleason score of 6 suggests a poorly differentiated tumor with a high risk of metastasis.
options.C: The Gleason score is determined by adding the two least common Gleason grades found in the
options.D: The Gleason score is irrelevant in determining the treatment approach for prostate cancer.

questions.explanation: Correct answer: A) The Gleason score indicates the stage of prostate cancer. Explanation: The Gleason score is a grading system used to evaluate the aggressiveness and prognosis of prostate cancer based on the microscopic appearance of tumor cells observed in biopsy samples. Grade group Score Description 1 ≤ 6 Only individual discrete well-formed glands. 2 3 + 4 Predominantly well-formed glands with a lesser component of poorly formed, fused or cribriform glands 3 4 + 3 Predominantly poorly formed/fused/cribriform glands with a lesser component of well-formed glands 4 (4 + 4/3 + 5/5 + 3) Only poorly formed/fused/cribriform glands or predominantly mix of well-formed glands and lack of glands 5 (4 + 5/5 + 4/5 + 5) Lack gland formation (or with necrosis) with or without poorly formed/fused/cribriform glands
questions.chapter_heading: Genital System-Pathology Of Male Genital Tract

questions.question: A 60-year-old male presents with increased frequency, nocturia, and a weak urine stream. Digital rectal examination reveals an enlarged prostate with a palpable nodule. A prostate biopsy is performed, and histological examination is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: Correct answer : B) Prostate Adenocarcinoma The case scenario describes a 60-year-old male with urinary symptoms and a palpable nodule on digital rectal examination, suggestive of prostate pathology. The histological features as seen include prominent nucleoli, perineural invasion, and an infiltrative growth pattern , which are characteristic of prostate adenocarcinoma. Features of Prostate Cancer: Prostate cancer cells form irregular glandular structures that may vary in size and shape. Glands may be crowded and back-to-back , lacking the normal orderly appearance seen in benign glands. Cells exhibit enlarged, hyperchromatic nuclei with prominent nucleoli. Perineural invasion is a common feature of prostate cancer and may indicate a higher risk of disease progression. Cancer cells infiltrate the surrounding tissues in an irregular, invasive manner. Immunohistochemical staining can be used to identify specific markers associated with prostate cancer, such as prostate-specific antigen (PSA), prostate-specific acid phosphatase (PSAP), androgen receptor (AR), and cytokeratins. Reference: Robbins and Cotran, Pathologic basis of disease, 10th Edition, Page 976
questions.chapter_heading: Genital System-Pathology Of Male Genital Tract

questions.question: Which of the following is a new biomarker used in Prostatic Cancer?
questions.explanation: Correct answer: C) NKX 3.1 Explanation: NKX3.1 is primarily expressed in the prostate, and its expression is regulated by androgens. It is involved in the maintenance of prostate epithelial cell differentiation, growth regulation, and suppression of cellular proliferation. NKX3.1 also has tumor suppressor functions, helping to maintain normal prostate architecture and function. Tumour markers for carcinoma of prostate: Prostate specific antigen (PSA). Prostatic acid phosphatase (PAP). PCA3. NKX 3.1. NMP22 (Option A) is used as a marker in bladder CA. Thymidine kinase(Option B) is used as a marker in leukemias. PLAP (Placental alkaline phosphatase) (Option D) is used as a marker in seminoma. Reference: Robbins and Cotran, Pathologic basis of disease, 10th edition, Page 97
questions.chapter_heading: Genital System-Pathology Of Male Genital Tract

questions.question: Which of the following is a protective factor associated with prostate cancer?
questions.explanation: Correct answer: D) Adequate levels of vitamin D Explanation: Adequate levels of vitamin D are considered a protective factor for prostate cancer. Vitamin D has been linked to a reduced risk of developing prostate cancer. Protective factors Risk factors Vitamin D Selenium Lycopene Soy products Age >60 years High fat diet Racial preponderance (Blacks > Whites) Intake of red meat Family history of Prostate CA Genetic factors BRCA 2 gene mutation (Chromosome 13). Hypermethylation of glutathione S-transferase. Chromosomal rearrangement juxtaposes TMPRSS-2 with ETS fusion gene. Reference: Robbins and Cotran, Pathologic basis of disease, 10th edition, Page 97
questions.chapter_heading: Genital System-Pathology Of Male Genital Tract

questions.question: A 65-year-old man presents with complaints of increased frequency and urgency of urination, particularly at night. He also mentions a feeling of incomplete bladder emptying and a weak urine stream. The patient's PSA level is within normal limits. The histopathology image is given below. Based on the diagnosis, which of the following is true?

options.B: Presence of atypical cells with high mitotic activity
options.C: Increased number of stromal and epithelial cells
options.D: Dysplastic changes in the glandular architecture

questions.explanation: Correct answer: C) Increased number of stromal and epithelial cells Explanation: Characteristic features of the histopathology of Benign Prostatic Hyperplasia (BPH) include: Hyperplasia (increase in the number of cells) of both stromal and epithelial components of the prostate gland. The stromal cells include fibroblasts and smooth muscle cells, while the epithelial cells line the glandular structures of the prostate. Reference: Robbins and Cotran, Pathologic basis of disease, 10th edition, Page 976
questions.chapter_heading: Genital System-Pathology Of Male Genital Tract

questions.question: Which zone of the prostate is primarily affected by benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH), and which zone is more commonly associated with prostate cancer?
questions.explanation: Correct answer: C) Transitional zone & Peripheral zone Explanation : Diseases Prostate zones Prostate cancer (adenocarcinoma) Peripheral Prostatic intraepithelial neoplasia Peripheral Prostatitis Central Benign prostatic hyperplasia Transitional Reference: Robbins and Cotran, Pathologic basis of disease, 10th edition, Page 976
questions.chapter_heading: Genital System-Pathology Of Male Genital Tract

questions.question: Match the following tumour markers (Column A) with the corresponding testicular tumour types (Column B). Column A (Tumor Markers) Column B (Testicular Tumor Types) 1. Alpha-fetoprotein (AFP) A. Seminoma 2. Beta-human chorionic gonadotropin ( β -hCG) B. Embryonal Carcinoma 3. CD-30 C. Yolk sac tumour 4. Placental alkaline phosphatase (PLAP) D. Choriocarcinoma 5. Cytokeratin E. Teratoma
questions.explanation: Correct answer: C)1-C, 2-D, 3-B, 4-A, 5-E Explanation: The various testicular tumours and their markers are given below: Testicular Tumour Corresponding Tumor Markers Seminoma Placental alkaline phosphatase (PLAP) HCG LDH Newer markers: Oct 3/4, Nanog, CD117, SALL4 Embryonal Carcinoma CD-30 Yolk sac tumour Alpha-fetoprotein (AFP) Alpha-1 antitrypsin Choriocarcinoma Beta-human chorionic gonadotropin ( β -hCG) Teratoma Cytokeratin Reference: Robbins and Cotran, Pathologic basis of disease, 10th edition, Page 969
questions.chapter_heading: Genital System-Pathology Of Male Genital Tract

questions.question: The histological examination of a normal testis is given in the image below. Which of the following callouts is responsible for maintaining the blood testis barrier?
questions.explanation: Correct answer: B) 2 Explanation: The callouts given in the illustration correspond to the following. 1- Interstitial cell of Leydig. 2- Sertoli/sustentacular cell. 3- Spermatocyte. 4- Spermatogonium. Sertoli cells / sustentacular cells form the blood testis barrier. Reference: Inderbir Singh Histology, 9th edition, Pages 550-552, 882.
questions.chapter_heading: Genital System-Pathology Of Male Genital Tract

questions.question: A 10-month-old boy was referred to the hospital with non-palpable right testes. The physical examination revealed no jaundice, palpable left testes, or right-sided abdominal mass. Subsequent surgical excision of the mass revealed a cystic mass with keratinous debris, and a biopsy image of the specimen was obtained. All of the following statements regarding this condition are true except? stroma.

options.A: Typically present as well-defined, encapsulated masses with cystic and solid components.
options.B: Often associated with areas of haemorrhage and necrosis.
options.C: Histologically, it contains differentiated cells or organoid structures embedded in a fibrous or myxoid
options.D: Demonstrate homogeneous appearance and are mostly found malignant in young children.

questions.explanation: young children. Correct answer: D) Demonstrate homogeneous appearance and are mostly found malignant in young children. Explanation: Teratoma : Germ cell tumours (GCTs) having various organoid components derived from multiple germ layers. It can occur at any age, from infancy to adulthood. Prepubertal teratoma: Pure teratomas are common in infants and children. Mostly benign, resembling normal tissue. (Option D). Can present as undescended testicular teratoma. Postpubertal adult teratomas: Malignant transformation to squamous cell carcinoma, adenocarcinoma, or sarcoma. Histopathology: Gross: Adult teratomas are usually large (5 to 10 cm). Heterogeneous appearance with a well-defined encapsulated mass containing solid, cartilaginous, and cystic areas. (Option A). Associated with foci of haemorrhage and necrosis. (Option B). Microscopy: Differentiated cells or organoid structures, such as neural tissue, muscle, cartilage, epidermal-like surfaces, thyroid gland, and intestinal wall or brain substance embedded in a fibrous or myxoid stroma. (Option C) Special types include dermoid cysts containing hair, teeth, and skin. Reference: Robbins and Cotran, Pathologic Basis of Disease, 10th edition, Pages 966-67
questions.chapter_heading: Genital System-Pathology Of Male Genital Tract

questions.question: A 30-year-old male presents with a rapidly enlarging testicular mass associated with testicular pain and gynecomastia. He reports associated mild hemoptysis for the last 4 days. A biopsy of the mass is performed, and both gross and microscopic images are obtained. What is the most likely diagnosis based on the clinical presentation?
questions.explanation: Correct answer: A) Choriocarcinoma Explanation: Choriocarcinoma: Highly malignant type of GCT. Elevated serum hCG (human chorionic gonadotropin) elevated. Histopathology: Gross: Haemorrhage and necrosis
questions.chapter_heading: Genital System-Pathology Of Male Genital Tract

questions.question: A 10-year-old male with a painless testicular mass for the past few months. On examination, the right testis was enlarged and the transillumination test was negative. A biopsy of the mass was performed and is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: Correct answer: B) Yolk Sac tumour Explanation: Yolk Sac Tumour or endodermal sinus tumour: Common in infants and children up to 3 years old. Morphology: Gross: Solid grey-white with a gelatinous or mucoid appearance. Microscopy: 50% of the tumours show a lace-like network of medium-sized cuboidal, flattened, or spindled cells with endodermal sinuses ( Schiller-Duval or glomerular bodies ). Eosinophilic, hyaline-like globules containing α -fetoprotein (AFP) and α 1-antitrypsin are present. Choriocarcinoma on microscopy reveals cytotrophoblastic cells and syncytiotrophoblastic cells. ( Option B) Transillumination test is positive in hydrocele (fluid-filled sac) or spermatocele (cyst in the epididymis). ( Option D)
questions.chapter_heading: Genital System-Pathology Of Male Genital Tract

questions.question: A 65-year-old male presents to the hospital with a painless scrotal mass. Ultrasound scan reveals a solid testicular mass suspicious for a spermatocytic tumour. Upon further examination, the following histological findings are identified except?

options.A: Associated with gain of function mutation
options.B: Presence of inflammatory infiltrates and syncytiotrophoblasts
options.C: Presence of three intermixed cell distinct cell populations on microscopy
options.D: Low risk of metastasis following surgical resection

questions.explanation: Correct answer: B) Presence of inflammatory infiltrates and syncytiotrophoblasts Explanation: Spermatocytic tumours : Testicular germ cell neoplasm. Associated with gain of chromosome 9q (Option A). Affects over 60 years old. Histopathology: Microscopy (Option C): Smaller cells with dense chromatin and a narrow eosinophilic cytoplasm rim resembling secondary spermatocytes. Medium-sized cells containing a round nucleus, spireme-type chromatin with occasional nucleoli, and eosinophilic cytoplasm. Scattered giant cells , either uninucleate or multinucleate. Slow-growing tumour doesn’t metastasise (Option D). Excellent prognosis with surgical resection (Option B). Reference: Robbins and Cotran, Pathologic basis of disease, 10th edition, Page 970.
questions.chapter_heading: Genital System-Pathology Of Male Genital Tract

questions.question: A patient underwent unilateral orchiectomy for a swelling in the right testis. The specimen is sent for histopathological examination, and its microscopic appearance is depicted in the image below. Which of the following statements is true regarding the diagnosis?

options.A: 3 different sizes of tumour cells are seen
options.C: Tumor cells are arranged in sheets
options.D: Tumor cells have a watery-clear cytoplasm

questions.explanation: Correct answer: D) Tumor cells have a watery-clear cytoplasm Explanation: The given histopathological image shows features suggestive of testicular seminoma. Histology of seminoma: The classic seminoma cell is large and round to polyhedral with a distinct cell membrane and a large, central nucleus with one or two prominent nucleoli. The cytoplasm is clear or watery appearing and contains glycogen . The sheets are divided into poorly demarcated lobules by the septa of the fibrous tissue. The septa show lymphocytic infiltration (T lymphocytes). Seminoma : It is the most common germ cell tumour of the testis. A similar presentation in the ovary is called dysgerminoma , and germinoma is present in the pineal gland . Incidence: Peak incidence in the fourth decade. Genetics: Seminomas contain isochromosome 12p and express OCT3/4 & NANOG. Gross: Seminoma has a homogeneous, grey-white, lobulated cut surface, usually devoid of hemorrhage or necrosis . 3 different sizes of tumour cells (small, medium and giant cells) are seen in a case of spermatocytic seminoma. (Option A) Endodermal sinuses-like structures called Schiller-Duval bodies are present in the case of a yolk sac tumour. (Option B) Tumour cells are arranged in sheets with cleft-like spaces in case of an embryonal carcinoma. (Option C)
questions.chapter_heading: Genital System-Pathology Of Male Genital Tract

questions.question: Which of the following is not a germ cell tumour?
questions.explanation: Correct answer: D) Sertoli cell tumour Explanation: The classification of testicular tumours is given in the table below. Germ cell tumours Sex cord-stromal tumours Mixed Seminomatous: Seminoma. Spermatocytic seminoma. Sertoli cell tumour. Leydig cell tumour. Pure tumours. Gonadoblastoma. Non-seminomatous: Embryonal carcinoma. Choriocarcinoma. Yolk sac tumour. Teratoma. Reference: Robbins and Cotran, Pathologic basis of disease, 10th edition. Page 969
questions.chapter_heading: Genital System-Pathology Of Male Genital Tract

questions.question: A 1-year-old boy is brought to the pediatric clinic by his parents, who are concerned about the absence of his left testicle in the scrotum. On physical examination, the right testicle is palpable in the scrotum, but the left is not. All are true regarding this condition except?

options.A: It can occur in association with hypospadias.
options.B: The most common site of arrest of descent is the inguinal canal.
options.C: It is very commonly associated with a well-defined hormonal disorder.

questions.explanation: Correct answer: C) It is very commonly associated with a well-defined hormonal disorder. scrotal sac , associated with testicular dysfunction and an increased risk of testicular cancer. It usually occurs as an isolated anomaly but may be accompanied by other genitourinary tract malformations, such as hypospadias. (Option A) The normal descent of the testes occurs in two phases: Transabdominal phase: Mediated by Mullerian inhibiting substance. Inguinoscrotal phase: Mediated by the androgen-induced release of calcitonin-related gene peptide. Sites of arrest of descent: Inguinal canal (most common). (Option B) Abdomen (uncommon). Morphology: Gross: The testis is small, brown, and atrophic. Microscopic: Atrophic tubules with thickened basement membrane. The subsequent loss of spermatogonia leaves the tubules with only Sertoli cells. The Leydig cells are spared and appear relatively prominent. (Option D) Management: During the first year of life, most inguinal cryptorchid testes descend spontaneously into the scrotum. If it remains undescended, surgical correction by orchiopexy (placement in the scrotal sac) is required, preferably before the development of histologic changes (to be performed at 6-12 months). Reference: Robbins and Cotran, Pathologic Basis of Disease, 10th Edition, Pages 966-67.
questions.chapter_heading: Genital System-Pathology Of Male Genital Tract
